On-campus housing is provided to the President as a condition of employment and is non-taxable under IRC-119. Dues paid at a local private club allow the President's Office to host college functions at that facility since the club does not allow corporate memberships. Because the President does not make personal use of the club, the benefit is considered non-taxable.

The College has a Total Compensation Philosophy which has been approved by the Compensation Committee of the Board of Trustees and has been communicated to all staff. Compensation for the President and Officers is targeted at the median of the defined peer group. The peer group of colleges includes the Associated Colleges of the Midwest (ACM)and the Great Lakes Colleges Association (GLCA). The Compensation Committee periodically reviews IRS Form 990 filings from both groups as well as the ACM and GLCA and CUPA surveys to ensure that total compensation levels for the President and Officers conforms to the approved total compensation policy.

The Board of Trustees established a 457(f) Plan for the President of the College for the period June 1, 2014 through year 2017. Amount accrued to the Plan in fiscal year 2016-2017 was $103,250. Cumulative amount credited to the 457(f) Plan to date was $205,146. Full vesting will occur on May 31, 2018, at which time the President will be eligible to receive the full distribution. Interest is credited using the prime rate.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Form Sch J Part I Line 3
ExplntnTxt: COMPENSATION OF THE TOP MANAGEMENT OFFICIAL PRESIDENT/CEO'S COMPENSATION 1. ANNUALLY THE PRESIDENT ESTABLISHES HIS PERFORMANCE GOALS IN CONSULTATION WITH THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE AND THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES. 2. ANNUALLY THE PRESIDENT REVIEWS HIS PROGRESS ON THOSE GOALS WITH THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE WHO DOCUMENTS A PERFORMANCE REVIEW WITH THE PRESIDENT. 3. PERIODICALLY, THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE PERFORMS A COMPARATIVE REVIEW OF THE PRESIDENT'S COMPENSATION AGAINST THE ORGANIZATION'S PEER INSTITUTIONS. 4. PERIODICALLY AND IN CERTAIN CASES (I.E. THE ARRIVAL OF A NEW PRESIDENT), AN OUTSIDE COMPENSATION CONSULTANT MAY ADVISE THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE ON PRESIDENTIAL COMPENSATION. 5. BASED ON THE ABOVE, THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE ESTABLISHES THE PRESIDENT'S COMPENSATION FOR THE FOLLOWING YEAR. 6. THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE DOCUMENTS THE REASONS FOR ESTABLISHING THE NEW COMPENSATION AMOUNT. 7. THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE THEN RENEWS THE PRESIDENT'S CONTRACT FOR AN ADDITIONAL TERM AT THE NEW COMPENSATION LEVEL.

Per direction from the Board of Trustees and in accordance with IRC Section 119, the President of the University resides on campus in University provided non-taxable housing with a yearly rental value of $24,000.

As a requirement of the position, the President and his family reside in college-owned housing (the value of which is not included as a taxable benefit.) The college provides all maintenance services and two part time housekeepers to clean the residence, both public spaces used for college-sponsored events and private spaces for the family's personal use. The housekeepers also do laundry, run errands and any other personal service requested by the President and his wife. The college pays for membership dues for the President at a local country club for purposes of entertaining donors and holding college-sponsored events as well as allowing the President and his family use of the facilities. The President reimburses the college for expenses incurred by his family for non-college activities (golf fees, meals, etc.)
The Compensation Committee is made up of members of the Board of Trustees

The target opportunity for the discretionary award is established through market compensation and internal policy so as to relate pay, performance and rewards. Upon reviewing annual performance, the Executive Committee of the Board of Trustees determines results and the granting of discretionary awards, if any.

The University owns a Presidential Residence. By contract, the President is required to live in the residence and host regular events for the University throughout the year. He attends for community service, outreach and fundraising opportunities. A portion of the benefits listed were treated as taxable compensation to the President.

The employee who qualifies for a supplemental nonqualified retirement plan will earn a fixed amount of credit and eligible interest to his or her deferred compensation account. The right of the employee to receive the amounts is contingent upon his or her continued performance in accordance with the employment agreement. IN RECOGNITION OF THE UNIQUE ROLE OF THE PRESIDENT IN REPRESENTING THE UNIVERSITY, THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS OF JOHN CARROLL UNIVERSITY REQUIRES THE PRESIDENT, AS A CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT, TO LIVE IN A RESIDENCE CONTIGUOUS TO THE UNIVERSITY AND SUITABLE FOR CARRYING OUT THEIR ROLE AND REQUIRED OFFICIAL DUTIES. AS PART OF THEIR OFFICIAL DUTIES, THE PRESIDENT IS RESPONSIBLE FOR EXTENDING OFFICIAL HOSPITALITY TO IMPORTANT VISITORS AND GUESTS IN CONJUNCTION WITH OFFICIAL FUNCTIONS (I.E., CAMPUS ACTIVITIES, ALUMNI AND ADVANCEMENT EVENTS, ETC.). MAID SERVICES ARE PROVIDED TO THE PRESIDENT FOR THE UNIVERSITY OWNED RESIDENCE IN WHICH THEY RESIDE. NO TAXABLE INCOME IS IMPUTED FOR THESE BENEFITS. THE UNIVERSITY'S TRAVEL EXPENSE POLICY PROHIBITS THE PURCHASE OF FIRST-CLASS AIR TRAVEL OR THE EQUIVALENT AT THE UNIVERSITY'S EXPENSE. HOWEVER, FIRST-CLASS TRAVEL OR THE EQUIVALENT IS PERMITTED IN CERTAIN LIMITED CIRCUMSTANCES IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE PRESIDENT'S EMPLOYMENT CONTRACT WHICH HAS BEEN REVIEWED AND APPROVED BY THE BOARD OF DIRECTOR'S EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE.

ON JULY 1, 2008 THE UNIVERSITY ENACTED A QUALIFIED PRIVATE 457(b) DEFERRED COMPENSATION PLAN FOR CERTAIN EMPLOYEES WITH ANY EMPLOYER CONTRIBUTIONS TO BE MADE ON A DISCRETIONARY BASIS. THE UNIVERSITY MADE NO CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE 457 PLAN IN FISCAL 2017. ANY AND ALL CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE PLAN IN FISCAL YEAR 2017 WERE VOLUNTARY EMPLOYEE CONTRIBUTIONS. THE PRESIDENT OF THE UNIVERSITY, FR. ROBERT NIEHOFF, SJ, IS A JESUIT PRIEST AND MEMBER OF THE SOCIETY OF JESUS (SJ), A RELIGIOUS ORDER OF THE CATHOLIC CHURCH. IN KEEPING WITH HIS RELIGIOUS VOWS, THE PRESIDENT DOES NOT RECEIVE DIRECT COMPENSATION FROM THE UNIVERSITY. COMPENSATION AND BENEFITS FOR SERVICES PROVIDED BY MEMBERS OF THE SOCIETY OF JESUS ARE PAID DIRECTLY AND IN THE AGGREGATE TO JOHN CARROLL JESUIT COMMUNITY CORPORATION, RATHER THAN TO EACH MEMBER INDIVIDUALLY. GENERAL BOARD OF DIRECTORS MEETINGS ARE HELD AT LEAST THREE TIMES ANNUALLY, WITH EACH MEETING GENERALLY HELD OVER A TWO-DAY PERIOD. IN ADDITION, BOARD COMMITTEES, INCLUDING ACADEMIC AFFAIRS; AUDIT; CORPORATE GOVERNANCE AND NOMINATING; ADVANCEMENT; EXECUTIVE; FINANCE; HUMAN RESOURCES; INVESTMENTS; PROPERTY, FACILITIES AND IT; STUDENT AFFAIRS; AND MISSION AND IDENTITY MEET AS NECESSARY BUT AT LEAST THREE TIMES ANNUALLY.

First-class travel may be paid by the College for international flights and rail transportation. Housing: As a condition of employment, the President is required to reside in College-owned housing. The house must be and is used for College business and College-sponsored functions. A housing expense allowance is provided. The estimated value of housing costs for the President is excluded from taxable income but disclosed in Schedule J Column D Nontaxable benefits $52,985. The College made a payment with tax gross-up to President Cassidy which appears in Column B(iii) on Schedule J of $23,672.

The compensation of officers and key employees is determined by an annual review of current independent salary surveys. The Executive Committee of the Board of Trustees approves the compensation of the President and gives final approval to compensation for all other officers and key employees based on the President's recommendations. The President of the College has an employment contract.

The College reports three different categories of non-fixed payments on Schedule J, Part II. Bonuses are reported on Schedule J, Part II Column B(ii). Bonuses are based on a number of variables including but not limited to individual goal achievements as well as operational achievements of the College. At times, bonuses are a one-time payment when an employee has taken on additional temporary duties. The final decision of the bonus amount is determined as part of the overall compensation review and is approved by the Executive Committee of the Board of Trustees for the President of the College and for others by the College President. Taxable income in lieu of College Pension contribution and vacation payouts are reported on Schedule J, Part II Column B(iii).
The College provided non-taxable housing to the Assistant Clerk/VP Special Assistant to the President as part of her compensation.

During the calendar year ended december 31, 2016 the college offered retirement plans pursuant to section 457(f) of the Internal Revenue code for certain employees, as follows: Michael Alexander, $40,000

As detailed on Schedule J, Part II, bonuses were awarded to certain employees during the year. A bonus was awarded to the president of the college at the recommendation of the executive compensation committee and upon the approval of the board of trustees. Bonuses to all other persons were awarded at the discretion of the president of the college.

The University furnishes the President and his family with housing owned by the University, which is required as a condition of employment. The President and his family will reside in the home throughout his term. The house is also used to host University-related functions. This benefit was not included in taxable compensation as it qualifies for exclusion under Internal Revenue Code Section 119(d) due to being required as a condition of employment and for the convenience of the employer. The University is responsible for paying the cost of all utilities and reasonable expenses, including maintenance and renovations to the president's residence and grounds and excluding personal telephone charges. The University pays dues for memberships in such professional and community associations and organizations, and for attendance by the President at conferences and meetings, as deemed appropriate for the President's execution of the duties of his office. This includes membership fees to the Westmoreland Club and Huntsville Golf Club. These benefits are not included in the President's taxable compensation given the business nature surrounding these memberships.

THOMAS BOTZMAN, THE PRESIDENT, PARTICIPATES IN A NON-QUALIFIED PLAN. THE UNIVERSITY CONTRIBUTED $25,000 TO THE PLAN DURING THE FISCAL YEAR. An officer who separated from the organization during the fiscal year received a severance payment.

THE PRESIDENT OF THE UNIVERSITY MAY RECEIVE AN INCENTIVE-BASED ANNUAL BONUS AT THE DISCRETION OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES. THE DECISION TO AWARD A BONUS IS BASED UPON THE PRESIDENT'S PERFORMANCE DURING THE PREVIOUS YEAR AND MEASURED AGAINST THE GOALS, OBJECTIVES, AND EXPECTATIONS MUTUALLY ESTABLISHED BY THE PRESIDENT AND THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES ANNUALLY.

THE COLLEGE PAID FOR HEALTH AND SOCIAL CLUB DUES OR COUNTRY CLUB DUES FOR FOUR OF THE OFFICERS/HIGHEST COMPENSATED EMPLOYEES LISTED IN PART VII. CANISIUS WILL ONLY REIMBURSE A BUSINESS EXPENSE WHEN ALL THREE OF THE FOLLOWING IRS REQUIREMENTS ARE MET: 1) THE EXPENSE MUST HAVE A BUSINESS CONNECTION (I.E., THE EXPENSES MUST BE INCURRED WHILE PERFORMING SERVICES ON BEHALF OF THE COLLEGE) 2) THE EXPENSES MUST BE ADEQUATELY SUBSTANTIATED BY THE EMPLOYEE WITHIN A REASONABLE PERIOD OF TIME; AND 3) THE EMPLOYEE MUST RETURN ANY EXCESS REIMBURSEMENT OF ALLOWANCE WITHIN A REASONABLE PERIOD OF TIME. A PORTION OF THESE DUES WERE TAXABLE BASED ON THE PERCENTAGE OF NON-BUSINESS TO BUSINESS USE FOR EACH EMPLOYEE. THE COLLEGE "GROSSED UP" THE APPLICABLE NON-BUSINESS EXPENSES AND INCLUDED IN THE EMPLOYEES' W-2 AS ADDITIONAL TAXABLE COMPENSATION.
Robert Grant, VP of Advancement, was paid a $60,000 severance payment.

THE UNIVERSITY'S TRAVEL POLICY PROVIDES THAT EXPENSES INCURRED BY SPOUSES ARE NOT REIMBURSABLE UNLESS THE SPOUSE IS TRAVELING FOR A BONA FIDE BUSINESS PURPOSE AND THE TRAVEL HAS BEEN APPROVED. ANY EXCEPTIONS TO THE POLICY REQUIRE APPROVAL BY THE APPROPRIATE UNIVERSITY OFFICER. ALL SPOUSAL TRAVEL IS PROCESSED UNDER THE PROVISIONS OF THE TAX DEPARTMENT'S SPOUSAL TRAVEL POLICY WHICH PROVIDES FOR EVALUATING THE TAXABLE COMPONENT, IF ANY, OF THE TRAVEL AND THE APPROPRIATE TAX TREATMENT AND REPORTING. ALL SPOUSAL TRAVEL REGARDING PRESIDENT TURNER ALSO REQUIRES THE REVIEW AND APPROVAL OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES AUDIT COMMITTEE CHAIR. APPROPRIATE APPROVALS IN ACCORDANCE WITH POLICY ARE REQUIRED PRIOR TO REIMBURSEMENT. the president is a participant in a non-qualified plan. the organization contributed $18,000 to the plan during the fiscal year.

The college pays membership dues to local social clubs for the President, the Dean of the Law School, and the Vice President for Institutional Advancement. The benefit is not treated as taxable compensation as there is a bona fide business purpose to membership in these clubs, as the clubs are used for meetings and networking relating to college business. Any meals or other activities which the officer deems to be for his/her own personal use are treated as taxable compensation to him/her. The President of the college travels by first or business class accomodation for flights that are cross country or international. Coach class is used for shorter duration flights. These flights are not considered taxable. Also, expenses are reimbursed to the college President for spousal travel. When such travel is not for bona fide business purposes the reimbursements are treated as taxable compensation. A non-taxable housing benefit is provided to the college President.

Annual bonus payments were made to certain officers of the organization. The Board of Trustees Compensation Committee approved the President's bonus, while other bonus payments were approved by the President. The payments were based upon the individual officer's performance and the general financial condition of the organization.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE J, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 1A
ExplntnTxt: UNDER IRC SECT 119(A) THE VALUE OF LODGING PROVIDED IN-KIND TO AN EMPLOYEE (THE PRESIDENT) FOR THE CONVENIENCE OF THE EMPLOYER IS EXCLUDABLE FROM GROSS INCOME IF THE EMPLOYEE IS REQUIRED TO ACCEPT SUCH LODGING ON THE BUSINESS PREMISES OF THE EMPLOYER AS A CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT. THE COLLEGE REQUIRES AND FURNISHES A HOME FOR THE PRESIDENT'S USE AS A CONDITION OF HIS EMPLOYMENT. THE PRESIDENT IS TO USE THE HOME TO ENTERTAIN OR HOLD MEETINGS FOR BOARD MEMBERS, VARIOUS COLLEGE EMPLOYEES, POTENTIAL DONORS, AND STUDENTS. THIS IS A SCHOOL POLICY AND IS PART OF HIS EMPLOYMENT CONTRACT. THE PRESIDENT HAS USED THE RESIDENCE EXTENSIVELY FOR COLLEGE BUSINESS. HE HAS AN OFFICE IN THE HOUSE SOLELY DESIGNATED FOR COLLEGE WORK THAT HE USES EACH DAY AND ON WEEKENDS. THE PRESIDENT ENTERTAINS THE TRUSTEES WHICH DROP BY CONTINUOUSLY THROUGHOUT THE YEAR. THE PRESIDENT WILL HOLD CABINET MEETINGS AT THE HOUSE PERIODICALLY. MEETINGS WITH COMMUNITY OFFICIALS OCCUR FREQUENTLY AT THE HOUSE. THE PRESIDENT MEETS POTENTIAL AND LONG-TIME DONORS AT HIS HOME SEVERAL TIMES A MONTH TO SECURE CONTRIBUTIONS FOR THE COLLEGE. HE HOLDS A FRESHMAN SEMINAR CLASS AT THE HOME SEVERAL TIMES A MONTH. THE PRESIDENT HAS ALSO ALLOWED STUDENTS TO STAY AT THE HOUSE FOR SHORT STAYS WHEN NEEDED. HIS HOME IS ALWAYS OPEN TO STUDENTS TO DROP BY AND VISIT. THE PRESIDENT PERFORMS A MEANINGFUL PORTION OF HIS DUTIES AT HIS HOME.

Housing for the President is paid for by the University. The exclusion rules under Sect. 119 are not met and as a result, the allowance is taxable compensation to the President and is properly recorded as such on his W-2. THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES A COUNTRY CLUB MEMBERSHIP IN THE PRESIDENT'S NAME THAT IS USED FOR BUSINESS RELATED ENTERTAINING. ON OCCASION, THE UNIVERSITY HAS PURCHASED FIRST CLASS COMMERCIAL AIRFARE FOR THE PRESIDENT WHEN HIS SCHEDULE AND/OR SEAT AVAILABILITY REQUIRE IT. THE UNIVERSITY DOES NOT PROVIDE CHARTER AIR TRAVEL.

PRESIDENT IS REIMBURSED FOR 50% OF THE COST FOR HAVING THE HOUSE CLEANED. THE HOME IS USED TO HOST MANY OF THE UNIVERSITY'S EVENTS. AS SUCH, THE PORTION OF THE CLEANING COSTS REIMBURSED BY THE UNIVERSITY IS CONSIDERED A BUSINESS EXPENSE TO THE UNIVERSITY AND IS NOT CONSIDERED TAXABLE INCOME TO THE PRESIDENT. EMPLOYMENT AGREEMENT STATES COE COLLEGE REQUIRES THAT ITS PRESIDENT LIVE IN A PRESIDENT'S HOUSE OR MANSE OWNED BY THE COLLEGE BECAUSE OF ITS REQUIREMENT THAT THE PRESIDENT CONDUCT SIGNIFICANT BUSINESS ACTIVITIES AND REGULARLY HOST COLLEGE RELATED EVENTS AND ENTERTAINMENT ON COLLEGE PROPERTY. THE PRESIDENT IS REQUIRED TO MAINTAIN AN OFFICE AT THE MANSE IN ORDER FOR HIM TO BE AVAILABLE TO ATTEND TO THE RESPONSIBILITIES OF HIS OFFICE AND THE BUSINESS OF THE COLLEGE AT ALL TIMES, AS IT IS NOT PRACTICAL FOR HIM TO DISCHARGE HIS DUTIES AS PRESIDENT SOLELY FROM HIS OFFICE ON THE CAMPUS, BECAUSE HIS RESPONSIBILITIES OFTEN REQUIRE THAT HE WORK OUTSIDE NORMAL BUSINESS HOURS AND THAT HE NEEDS TO BE ABLE TO ADDRESS ANY COLLEGE RELATED EMERGENCIES THAT MAY ARISE OUTSIDE OF NORMAL BUSINESS HOURS. IN ADDITION, THE SPACE AND OTHER REQUIREMENTS ASSOCIATED WITH THE CONDUCT OF LARGE STUDENT AND ALUMNI EVENTS AND OTHER FUNCTIONS FOR FRIENDS OF THE COLLEGE REQUIRE A RESIDENCE OF THE SIZE AND LOCATION OF THE MANSE. THE RESIDENCE LOCATED AT 370 34TH STREET SE, CEDAR RAPIDS, IOWA, WHICH IS OWNED BY THE COLLEGE, IS DESIGNATED THE OFFICIAL COLLEGE MANOR. THE PRESIDENT'S EMPLOYMENT AGREEMENT REQUIRES COE COLLEGE TO PAY ALL INSURANCE COSTS, UTILITIES AND MAINTENANCE EXPENSES RESULTING FROM THE PRESIDENT'S RESIDING IN THE MANSE, AND OBLIGATES THE PRESIDENT TO PAY THE COSTS OF ORDINARY DAY-TO-DAY LIVING EXPENSES OF LIVING IN THE MANSE, INCLUDING, WITHOUT LIMITATION, LAWN CARE AND SNOW REMOVAL (EXCEPT WHEN ASSOCIATED WITH A COLLEGE-RELATED EVENT), LAUNDRY AND CLEANING SUPPLIES, AND TELEVISION, INTERNET AND TELEPHONE SERVICES. EXPENSES RELATING TO THE MANSE IN THE 2017 FISCAL YEAR WERE ALLOCATED AND PAID IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE EMPLOYMENT AGREEMENT AND ORDINARY LIVING EXPENSES PAID BY THE COLLEGE WERE INCLUDED IN THE PRESIDENT'S TAXABLE COMPENSATION. ExplntnTxt: THE $543,494 FIGURE FOR THE PRESIDENT INCLUDES PAYMENTS AND BENEFITS TO THE PRESIDENT IN THE 2016 CALENDAR YEAR, AS WELL AS PAYMENTS THAT WILL BE MADE IN FUTURE CALENDAR YEARS AS LONG AS HE CONTINUTES TO PERFORM SUBSTANTIAL SERVICES FOR THE COLLEGE THROUGH SPECIFIED DATES IN THOSE FUTURE YEARS. BEFORE APPROVING THE PRESIDENT'S TOTAL COMPENSATION AND BENEFIT PACKAGE, THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF THE COLLEGE REVIEWED COMPENSATION AND BENEFIT DATA FOR COMPARABLE INSTITUTIONS, AND VERIFIED THAT THE TOTAL COMPENSATION AND BENEFITS PACKAGE OF THE PRESIDENT WAS REASONABLE IN LIGHT OF SUCH DATA.

EFFECTIVE JULY 1, 2003, THE UNIVERSITY ADOPTED THE SUPPLEMENTAL RETENTION AND RETIREMENT PLAN (SERRP), AN UNFUNDED DEFINED BENEFIT RETIREMENT PLAN FOR SENIOR EXECUTIVES. THE PURPOSE OF THE PLAN IS TO REWARD PERFORMANCE, LOYALTY AND CONTINUOUS SERVICE OF THOSE INDIVIDUALS SELECTED AS PARTICIPANTS IN THE PLAN. UNDER THE TERMS OF THE PLAN, THE UNIVERSITY WILL PAY PARTICIPANTS THE LUMP SUM EQUIVALENT VALUE OF A LIFE ANNUITY PAYING 60% OF THE AVERAGE OF THE PARTICIPANT'S THREE FINAL CALENDAR YEARS OF BASE SALARY AND ANNUAL INCENTIVE COMPENSATION. THE BENEFIT IS OFFSET FOR EMPLOYER CONTRIBUTIONS (AND RELATED EARNINGS) TO THE 403(B) SAVINGS PLAN AS WELL AS THE EMPLOYER-PROVIDED PORTION OF SOCIAL SECURITY. SERRP BENEFITS VEST UPON A PARTICIPANT ATTAINING AGE 65 WITH 25 YEARS OF SERVICE. ANY PARTICIPANT WHO LEAVES THE SERVICE OF THE UNIVERSITY BEFORE REACHING BOTH OF THESE MILESTONES IS NOT ELIGIBLE TO RECEIVE A BENEFIT FROM THE PLAN. EFFECTIVE DECEMBER 31, 2014, THE ACTUARIAL EQUIVALENT LUMP SUM BENEFIT PAYABLE AT AGE 65 WAS SET AT A FIXED AMOUNT FOR ALL BUT 1 GRANDFATHERED PARTICIPANT. WHILE THE CHANGE IN THE PRESENT VALUE INCLUDES CHANGES IN THE DISCOUNT RATE USED FOR ACCOUNTING PURPOSES, THE ACTUAL LUMP SUM IS BASED ON A FIXED INTEREST RATE OF 6%. THE AMOUNTS REPORTED IN THIS FORM 990 REPRESENT THE INCREASE IN THE PRESENT VALUE OF THE ACCRUED BENEFIT (WITHOUT REGARD TO VESTING). THE NET INCREASE IN THE PRESENT VALUE OF THE ACCRUED BENEFIT BY PARTICIPANTS INCLUDED ON SCHEDULE J IS: HEATHER A. O'CONNELL,$114,379; CAROLE D. PITCHER, $88,447; PETER BAILEY $77,668; ERIN DIMARCO, $37,302 AND JAMES WILSON, JR. $52,026. DR. HARMON WAS ALSO A PARTICIPANT IN THE SERRP; HOWEVER, SHE REACHED THE VESTING REQUIREMENTS IN THE PLAN ON JANUARY 1, 2016, WHICH RESULTED IN A FULL PAYOUT OF HER SERRP BENEFIT. THE VAST MAJORITY OF HER SERRP BENEFIT WAS DISCLOSED IN PRIOR FORMS 990.

THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES BONUSES TO THE INDIVIDUALS LISTED ON SCHEDULE J. IT UTILIZES A NUMBER OF PERFORMANCE OBJECTIVES TO DETERMINE THE BONUS AMOUNTS. THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES MEETS TO SPECIFICALLY DISCUSS EXECUTIVE BONUS AMOUNTS. THE COMMITTEE UTILIZES AN INDEPENDENT COMPENSATION CONSULTANT THAT PROVIDES INFORMATION FROM A VARIETY OF COMPENSATION STUDIES AND SURVEYS INCLUDING 990'S. THE COMMITTEE FOLLOWED THE PROCESS TO ESTABLISH THE PRESUMPTION THAT COMPENSATION PAID TO THE ORGANIZATION'S PRESIDENT AND OTHER TOP MANAGEMENT FOR PURPOSES OF SECTION 4958 BY RELYING ON PROFESSIONAL ADVICE IN THE WRITTEN OPINION OF REASONABLENESS FROM THE INDEPENDENT COMPENSATION CONSULTANT. ONCE ALL OF THIS INFORMATION IS GATHERED AND REVIEWED, THE COMMITTEE APPROVES THE BONUS FOR EACH EXECUTIVE. ALL COMPENSATION, INCLUDING COMPENSATION COMMITTEE APPROVED BONUSES, ARE REPORTED TO THE FULL BOARD OF TRUSTEES.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE J, PART I, LINE 1A AND LINE 1B:
ExplntnTxt: FIRST-CLASS TRAVEL: THE UNIVERSITY OF SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA REQUIRES THAT ECONOMY-CLASS (COACH) TRAVEL BE UTILIZED FOR UNIVERSITY BUSINESS. FIRST AND BUSINESS CLASS AIR TRAVEL IS ONLY ALLOWED WHEN THERE IS ADVANCE WRITTEN APPROVAL, WHEN IT IS NECESSARY FOR MEDICAL REASONS, OR WHEN COACH CLASS IS UNAVAILABLE. THERE IS NO VALUE INCLUDED IN THE INDIVIDUAL'S FORM W-2 AS TAXABLE INCOME AS ONLY BUSINESS TRAVEL EXPENSES ARE PAID. THE INDIVIDUALS LISTED IN FORM 990, PART VII WHO FLEW FIRST CLASS DURING CALENDAR YEAR 2016 INCLUDED SIX OFFICERS, FIVE KEY EMPLOYEES, THREE HIGHEST COMPENSATED EMPLOYEES AND ONE FORMER KEY EMPLOYEE. CHARTER TRAVEL: THE UNIVERSITY OF SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA UTILIZES CHARTER TRAVEL ON OCCASION FOR ATHLETIC TEAM EVENTS FOR CERTAIN INDIVIDUALS AS PART OF THEIR OFFICIAL RESPONSIBILITIES TO THE UNIVERSITY OF SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA. THERE IS NO VALUE INCLUDED IN THE INDIVIDUAL'S FORM W-2 AS TAXABLE INCOME AS ONLY BUSINESS TRAVEL EXPENSES ARE PAID. THE INDIVIDUALS LISTED IN FORM 990, PART VII WHO UTILIZED CHARTER TRAVEL DURING CALENDAR YEAR 2016 INCLUDED FOUR OFFICERS, TWO TRUSTEES, ONE KEY EMPLOYEE, AND ONE HIGHEST COMPENSATED EMPLOYEE. TRAVEL FOR COMPANIONS: THE UNIVERSITY OF SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA PAYS FOR COMPANION TRAVEL WHEN THERE IS A BUSINESS PURPOSE. THE AMOUNT IS NOT REPORTED ON THE EMPLOYEE's FORM W-2 AS TAXABLE INCOME AS ONLY BUSINESS TRAVEL EXPENSES ARE PAID. TO THE EXTENT THERE IS NO BUSINESS PURPOSE, THE EMPLOYEES ARE REQUIRED TO REIMBURSE THE UNIVERSITY FOR COMPANION TRAVEL. THE INDIVIDUALS LISTED IN FORM 990, PART VII WHO WERE PROVIDED WITH COMPANION TRAVEL FOR BUSINESS PURPOSES DURING CALENDAR YEAR 2016 INCLUDED THREE OFFICERS, TWO TRUSTEES, ONE KEY EMPLOYEE AND ONE HIGHEST COMPENSATED EMPLOYEE. HOUSING ALLOWANCE: ONE OFFICER AND ONE FORMER KEY EMPLOYEE RECEIVED A HOUSING ALLOWANCE DURING CALENDAR YEAR 2016 WHICH WAS PROVIDED FOR IN THEIR EMPLOYMENT CONTRACT AND WAS INCLUDED IN TAXABLE COMPENSATION ON FORM W-2. SUCH AMOUNTS ARE REPORTED ON SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN (B)(III). RESIDENCE FOR PERSONAL USE: LODGING PROVIDED IN THE PRESIDENT'S HOME (A UNIVERSITY BUILDING) TO THE PRESIDENT IS NOT REPORTED ON FORM W-2 AS TAXABLE INCOME AS THE PRESIDENT IS REQUIRED TO ACCEPT SUCH LODGING AS A CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT FOR THE CONVENIENCE OF THE UNIVERSITY. THE RENTAL VALUE OF THE PORTION OF THE PRESIDENT'S HOME THAT IS USED FOR PERSONAL PURPOSES IS INCLUDED AS A NONTAXABLE BENEFIT TO THE PRESIDENT AND IS REPORTED ON SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN (D). HEALTH OR SOCIAL CLUB DUES OR INITIATION FEES: PAYMENT TO OR REIMBURSEMENT FOR AN INDIVIDUAL'S MEMBERSHIP IN, OR DUES TO, A PRIVATE CLUB FOR BUSINESS PURPOSES IS MADE AVAILABLE IN CERTAIN EMPLOYMENT CONTRACTS OR IS OTHERWISE APPROVED BY THE APPLICABLE SENIOR VICE PRESIDENT Or THE PRESIDENT. THE VALUE OF MEMBERSHIPS PROVIDED FOR BUSINESS PURPOSES IS NOT INCLUDED IN AN INDIVIDUAL'S FORM W-2 AS TAXABLE INCOME. ANY PERSONAL USE OF THESE MEMBERSHIPS IS PAID FOR BY THE INDIVIDUAL. THE INDIVIDUALS LISTED IN FORM 990, PART VII WHO WERE PROVIDED WITH MEMBERSHIP IN, OR DUES TO, A PRIVATE CLUB DURING CALENDAR YEAR 2016 INCLUDED EIGHT OFFICERS, THREE KEY EMPLOYEES, TWO HIGHEST COMPENSATED EMPLOYEES, ONE FORMER OFFICER AND ONE FORMER KEY EMPLOYEE. PERSONAL SERVICES: CERTAIN INDIVIDUALS RECEIVED PERSONAL SERVICES, INCLUDING FINANCIAL PLANNING. SUCH SERVICES ARE MADE AVAILABLE IN EMPLOYMENT CONTRACTS and the value of the services, IF USED, WAS INCLUDED IN THE INDIVIDUALS' FORM W-2 AS TAXABLE INCOME AND IS REPORTED ON SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN (B)(III). THE LISTED INDIVIDUALS WHO RECEIVED SUCH BENEFIT DURING CALENDAR YEAR 2016 INCLUDED SIX OFFICERS, AND ONE HIGHEST COMPENSATED EMPLOYEE. ONE OFFICER RECEIVED THE SERVICES OF A CAR AND DRIVER. SUCH SERVICES WERE APPROVED AS PART OF HIS EMPLOYMENT CONTRACT, AND THE VALUE OF TAXABLE SERVICES WAS INCLUDED IN HIS FORM W-2 AS TAXABLE INCOME AND IS REPORTED ON SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN (B)(III).

OTHER: IN 1994 USC CREATED A 457(F) SUPPLEMENTAL RETIREMENT PLAN TO PROVIDE MAKE-UP BENEFITS TO EMPLOYEES WHOSE COMPENSATION EXCEEDS THE EARNINGS LIMITATION FOR CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE USC DEFINED CONTRIBUTION RETIREMENT PLAN. AS OF JANUARY 1, 2005, THE PLAN WAS FROZEN AND PARTICIPANTS, WITH RESPECT TO FUTURE MAKE-UP BENEFITS, WERE NO LONGER PERMITTED TO DEFER THESE BENEFITS. SCHEDULE J, PART I, LINE 7: CERTAIN INDIVIDUALS LISTED IN SCHEDULE J, PART II RECEIVED A MERIT BASED BONUS AND THE AMOUNT OF SUCH BONUSES ARE SHOWN ON SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN (B)(II). SEE ALSO LINE 4(B) DISCLOSURE FOR LISA ANN MAZZOCCO.
THE SR VP, FINANCE & CFO IS SERVING UNDER HIS INITIAL CONTRACT WITH THE UNIVERSITY.

THE CALIFORNIA STATE UNIVERSITY SAN MARCOS FOUNDATION DOES NOT COMPENSATE ANY EMPLOYEES. THE OFFICERS LISTED ON SCHEDULE J ARE EMPLOYEES OF THE RELATED ORGANIZATION, CALIFORNIA STATE UNIVERSITY SAN MARCOS. THE RELATED ORGANIZATION HAS POLICIES IN PLACE WHICH ARE USED TO DETERMINE COMPENSATION. THROUGH THE RELATED ORGANIZATION'S EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE - WHICH IS COMPRISED OF THE UNIVERSITY PRESIDENT WHO SERVES AS AN EX-OFFICIO MEMBER OF THE BOARD -COMPENSATION FOR THE ORGANIZATION'S OFFICERS IS REVIEWED ON AN ANNUAL BASIS. THE REVIEW OF CURRENT SALARY LEVELS FOR EACH EXECUTIVE EMPLOYEE IS PERFORMED BY ANALYZING EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION OF OTHER SIMILAR AUXILIARY ORGANIZATIONS WITHIN THE CALIFORNIA STATE UNIVERSITY SYSTEM, AS WELL AS SURVEYS OF OTHER NON-PROFIT CHARITABLE ORGANIZATIONS OF SIMILAR ASSET SIZE AND FUNCTIONS. THE EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE THEN RECOMMENDS THE APPROPRIATE SALARY LEVELS TO THE ORGANIZATION'S BOARD OF DIRECTORS FOR APPROVAL.

The University President is provided housing on campus, which is required of his position. Club membership dues are paid for certain of the employees listed on Schedule J and are included in box 5 W-2 wages.

As stated related to Line 1a, The University President is the only employee provided a residence, therefore there is no specific policy. The Club dues that are provided are specific to the related employee's employment contract instead of an overall policy.

SPOUSAL TRAVEL OCCURS IN VERY LIMITED CIRMCUMSTANCES FOR THE UNIVERSITY PRESIDENT AND SR VICE PRESIDENT OF UNIVERSITY ADVANCEMENT WHEN ATTENDING UNIVERSITY RELATED EVENTS AND FUNCTIONS. UNIVERSITY POLICY REQUIRES PRE-APPROVAL BY THE BOARD CHAIR AND WRITTEN SUBSTANTIATION OF THE BONA FIDE BUSINES PURPOSE WHEN ACCOMPANIED BY A SPOUSE. SPOUSAL TRAVEL IS TREATED AS TAXABLE COMPENSATION TO THE EMPLOYEE AS REQUIRED BY THE IRS WHEN IT IS NOT FOR A BONA FIDE UNIVERSITY BUSINESS PURPOSE. THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES REVIEWS DOCUMENTATION PRIOR TO TRAVEL. THE UNIVERSITY PRESIDENT RECEIVES AN ANNUAL HOUSING ALLOWANCE AND THE FORMER UNIVERSITY PRESIDENT ON ADMINISTRATIVE LEAVE RECEIVES AN HOUSING ALLOWANCE PURSUANT TO HIS EXECUTIVE CONTRACT. ALL HOUSING ALLOWANCE AMOUNTS ARE INCLUDED AS TAXABLE COMPENSATION ON FORM W-2. THE PRESIDENT IS REIMBURSED FOR AN ANNUAL CREDIT CARD MEMBERSHIP FEE WHICH IS PROVIDED SOLELY FOR UNIVERSITY BUSINESS RELATED TRAVEL. THE UNIVERSITY DOES NOT PROVIDE PAYMENT FOR PERSONAL SERVICES, TAX INDEMNIFICATIONS OR GROSS-UP PAYMENTS FOR ANY PERSON LISTED IN PART VII, SECTION A.

THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES COMPENSATION COMMITTEE IS RESPONSIBLE FOR MAKING RECOMMENDATIONS TO THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE CONCERNING COMPENSATION OF THE UNIVERSITY PRESIDENT, AND SETTING COMPENSATION AND OTHER TERMS AND CONDITIONS OF EMPLOYMENT FOR OFFICERS OF THE UNIVERSITY IN CONSULTATION WITH THE PRESIDENT. THE PROCESS FOR DETERMINING COMPENSATION INCLUDES RETAINING AN INDEPENDENT FIRM TRIENIALLY TO STUDY EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION TO ASSURE THAT THE COMPENSATION OF EACH OFFICER IS COMPARABLE TO POSITIONS OF SIMILARLY SITUATED ORGANIZATIONS. THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE IS ALSO RESPONSIBLE FOR CONDUCTING OR COMMISSIONING ANY OTHER NECESSARY SURVEY OR STUDIES AND REPORT THE RESULTS TO THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES. MEETINGS AND DECISIONS OF THIS COMMITTEE ARE DOCUMENTED CONTEMPORANEOUSLY IN COMMITTEE MINUTES.

The President's spouse will occasionally travel with him on certain university functions. There is a substantial business purpose for such travel, and the expenses are documented and retained on file.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 4b Supplemental nonqualified retirement plan
ExplntnTxt: The University maintains two nonqualified supplemental deferred compensation plans for the President, Dr. Kevin M. Ross, to supplement the retirement benefit program maintained by the University, and to encourage the retention of the President's services for a substantial period of time. The plans vested on July 1, 2016, and $869,940 was included in President Ross' 2016 taxable income accordingly. The University also accrued $100,000 into a nonqualified supplemental deferred compensation plan for President Ross during the year. The University maintains a Supplemental Executive Retirement Plan (SERP) to recognize the vital and substantial services rendered by the University's senior executives, and provide appropriate benefits in recognition of long, continuous service for the betterment of the University. The SERP constitutes an unfunded promise to pay, in the future, an annual benefit equal to a percentage of final average salary. Participants become 100% vested upon reaching retirement at the age of 65, assuming continuous service to the University. In the event of change in control of the University, or termination of the Plan, participants will receive a lump-sum distribution equal to the actuarially determined value of the plan benefit. No benefits were paid under the Executive Plan for the year. The change in actuarial value for each individual is as follows: Greg Malfitano $16,903; Laurie Levine $89,887. Additionally, the University maintains a deferred compensation plan for Gareth Fowles and Chris Boniforti, which will provide them each a one-time distribution of $75,000 if they are still employed at Lynn at the end of four years. The University accrued $20,455 each, for both Fowles and Boniforti, for the year ended June 30, 2017. The University also accrued $25,000 into a non-qualified deferred compensation plan for Sherrie Weldon during the year.

WRITTEN POLICY REGARDING PAYMENT OR REIMBURSEMENT OF EXPENSES: THE COLLEGE DOES NOT REIMBURSE FOR FIRST-CLASS TRAVEL. ON AN INFREQUENT BASIS, COLLEGE EMPLOYEES MAY TRAVEL WITH A BOARD OF TRUSTEE MEMBER ON A CHARTER (OR PRIVATELY-OWNED) PLANE ON COLLEGE BUSINESS. SUCH TRAVEL WOULD TYPICALLY INCLUDE THE PRESIDENT OF THE COLLEGE AND BE AUTHORIZED BY THAT PERSON. HOUSING ALLOWANCES ARE PROVIDED BY CONTRACT TO THE COLLEGE PRESIDENT IN LIEU OF COLLEGE-PROVIDED HOUSING. IN ADDITION, UNDER INTERNAL REVENUE SERVICE RULES, COLLEGE CLERGY MAY MAKE HOUSING ALLOWANCE ELECTIONS TO ALLOCATE A PORTION OF THEIR SALARY TO SUCH AN ALLOWANCE. PROVISION AND PAYMENT OF THESE BENEFITS ARE OUTLINED IN EACH INDIVIDUAL'S EMPLOYMENT CONTRACT.

TRAVEL FOR COMPANIONS: SPOUSAL TRAVEL IS PAID FOR BY THE COLLEGE WHEN THE SPOUSE ASSISTS THE BELOIT COLLEGE EMPLOYEE WITH THE COLLEGE BUSINESS ACTIVITIES IN PERFORMING SPECIFIC DUTIES. THE ONLY SUCH SPOUSAL TRAVEL, A NONTAXABLE BENEFIT, PAID FOR BY THE COLLEGE WAS THAT OF THE PRESIDENT'S SPOUSE IN THE AMOUNT OF $1,353. ALL EXPENDITURES MADE BY THE COLLEGE FOR TRAVEL OF THE SPOUSE WERE ATTRIBUTABLE TO SPECIFIC DUTIES IN FURTHERANCE OF THE MISSION OF THE COLLEGE. TAX INDEMNIFICATION AND GROSS-UP PAYMENTS: THE COLLEGE PAID $74 TO DR. CHRISTINA P. KLAWITTER IN 2016 AS A TAX GROSS-UP PAYMENT FOR MEDICARE TAX DUE. DISCRETIONARY SPENDING ACCOUNT: THE PRESIDENT HAS A NON-TAXABLE DISCRETIONARY SPENDING ACCOUNT OF $14,000. HOUSING ALLOWANCE OR RESIDENCE FOR PERSONAL USE/PERSONAL SERVICES: AS A CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT, THE PRESIDENT OF BELOIT COLLEGE IS REQUIRED TO RESIDE IN THE PRESIDENT'S HOUSE. THE PRESIDENT'S HOUSE SERVES BOTH AS A PERSONAL RESIDENCE AS WELL AS A VENUE FOR THE CARRYING ON OF COLLEGE BUSINESS REGULARLY. THE COLLEGE HAS DETERMINED THAT THE VALUE OF THE USE OF THIS PERSONAL RESIDENCE IS NOT CONSIDERED TAXABLE INCOME TO THE PRESIDENT AS PROVIDED FOR IN INTERNAL REVENUE CODE SECTION 119. CONSISTENT WITH THE USE OF THE RESIDENCE AS A VENUE FOR COLLEGE BUSINESS, A PART-TIME HOUSEKEEPER IS ASSIGNED TO CLEAN UP AND ASSIST WITH SUCH USE. THE VALUE OF THIS BENEFIT WAS $23,928 IN 2016. THE VALUE OF THE HOUSING ALLOWANCE WAS $44,367 IN 2016.

Compensation for the university president is set by the board of trustees based on a recommendation from the compensation committee of the board. The compensation committee consists of three members of the executive committee of the board. The committee gathers input from independent sources, including comparative university data. The president's compensation is then approved by the full board of trustees as well as by the sponsoring church denomination via its executive committee. The university chairperson (on behalf of the board) signs the president's annual statement of salary and benefits.

THE HOUSE SERVES AS A VENUE FOR MANY UNIVERSITY FUNCTIONS AND EVENTS AND HAS AN OFFICE FOR THE USE OF THE PRESIDENT AFTER REGULAR WORK HOURS AND WEEKENDS. THE VALUE OF THE HOUSING PROVIDED TO THE PRESIDENT IS $44,114 AND IS INCLUDED IN THE COMPENSATION INFORMATION PRESENTED IN PART VII OF THE FORM 990 AND IN SCHEDULE J. The University provided performance based bonus to one employee during the 2016 tax year. The bonus was specified as a fixed amount, after tax withholdings and other deductions. The full amounts, before tax withholdings and other deductions, were treated as taxable compensation to the employee.

SUE KING $ 12,155 COMPENSATION IS REPORTED ON THE FORM 990 IN THE YEAR THE COMPENSATION IS EARNED BY OR AWARDED TO AN INDIVIDUAL, EVEN IF THE COMPENSATION IS NOT PAID TO THE INDIVIDUAL, IS NOT FULLY VESTED, OR IS SUBJECT TO SUBSTANTIAL RISK OF FORFEITURE. IF COMPENSATION IS EARNED OR AWARDED IN ONE YEAR BUT PAID IN A LATER YEAR, THEN THE COMPENSATION IS GENERALLY REPORTED A SECOND TIME ON THE FORM 990 IN THE YEAR THE COMPENSATION IS PAID TO THE INDIVIDUAL. AS A RESULT OF THE REPORTING REQUIREMENT, AN ORGANIZATION COULD BE REQUIRED TO REPORT THE SAME COMPENSATION ON FORM 990 IN TWO DIFFERENT YEARS.

On an annual basis, the Executive Committee of the Board of Trustees reviews the President's salary. In July 2017, a nationally recognized consultant was engaged to conduct a compensation analysis for the President, Vice President and Dean positions. Their analysis report was submitted to Board Chair in September 2017. Recognizing the uniqueness of Olin College, they used four groups in their analysis: * National Private Independent Colleges and Universities with Significant Engineering Programs of Comparable Complexity to Olin * National Private Independent Colleges and Universities with Bachelor, Master's or Doctorate Programs of Similar Size * Predominantly Northeast Regional Top Liberal Arts Colleges * Private Independent Colleges and Universities in Massachusetts with Bachelor, Master's or Doctorate Programs of Similar Size. For each group, the consultant analyzed base salary, total cash compensation and total compensation for the 25th, 50th, 75th and 90th percentiles and adjusted the market data to a common effective date of July 1, 2017. A set of Composite Estimated Market Values was calculated to supplement the market values of each individual group. The Executive Committee used this data to develop a recommendation for the President's compensation which was reviewed and approved by the full Board of Trustees. The President used this data to develop recommendations for the compensation of the Vice Presidents and Deans which were reviewed and approved by the Executive Committee. All decisions regarding compensation are approved by independent persons and all deliberations and decisions are substantiated contemporaneously.

The University was founded by the Sisters of Mercy and has employees who are affiliated with this religious order. Because of the nature of the order and the poverty vows taken by Sisters listed on Form 990, Part VII, W-2 earnings are not reported as these employees are not directly taxable due to religious affiliation. Rather, their compensation is made payable primarily to the Sisters of Mercy and it is the order that determines what portion the employees will receive. Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a - (1) First Class or Charter Travel - The President is permitted to fly first class while certain other VPs are permitted if the trip is either cross country or international in nature, or if accompanying the President. To the extent the spouse of an employee permitted to fly first class is required to accompany them on a particular trip, these privileges extend to the spouse. The University did not use any charter travel during the reporting period. (2) Travel for Companions - the President is permitted to take his wife on certain trips that is furtherance of the advancement of the University. The Provost and certain other Vice Presidents who are involved in fund raising and entertainment events are occasionally permitted to take their spouses or companions on such trips. All costs associated with spousal travel are treated as compensation. (4) Discretionary Spending - the President, the Provost incurred certain travel expenses without having to account to the institution under the accountable plan rules. The Mercyhurst University Board of Trustees follows the recommendation of the Association of Governing Boards of Colleges and Universities among other leading authorities in our industry when dealing with presidential compensation and therefore, adheres to best practices established. The process/policy for setting presidential compensation at Mercyhurst University is the following. At Mercyhurst University, the Committee on Compensation of the Board of Trustees is responsible for the compensation-setting function of the President. The committee consists of no fewer than three trustees appointed by the chair of the board, who will also name a chair and vice chair. These trustees must be independent, without a conflict of interest as it relates to this area, and may not have been employed by Mercyhurst University in the last five years. No member may be an executive of Mercyhurst University. Continuously throughout the year, the Committee on Compensation evaluates the President's performance for the fiscal year-end and conducts a formal review at least once a year. The committee reviews the president's performance in light of the university's goals and objectives. In addition, the committee reviews the President's compensation to ensure that his compensation complies with rules governing tax-exempt universities described in the Internal Revenue Code, complies with compensation rules and regulations promulgated by any other regulatory agency or legislative authority and aligns appropriately with compensation levels at comparable universities. They use this review as the basis for recommendations on the president's compensation. The committee negotiates the terms of the (new or renewed) president's contract and increases in compensation level, elements of the compensation package, and structure. The recommendation is then presented for approval of the full board. At this time, the committee also requests the President to provide a list of goals and objectives for the institution and for the office of the president for the forthcoming year. This document provides the baseline used in evaluating the performance of the President. This request is followed up by a request of the Committee on Compensation to the President to prepare a report that assesses progress on each of the annual and standing objectives presented in the report.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a First-class or charter travel
ExplntnTxt: The University does not pay the cost of first class travel. While individuals may choose to travel first class, the University will pay up to the cost of coach or economy class travel. Any exceptions to this policy require the written approval of the President or Vice President for Business & Finance, obtained in advance of travel. Employees are permitted to use personal airline miles, "points," or other for upgrades; however, the University will not reimburse employees for the value of these upgrades. During the calendar year 2016 there were three exceptions granted to approve first class travel. One exception was allowed due to injuries the employee had, to allow for more comfort during the flight. The other two were approved per the employee's contract. The value of the first class travel was considered a necessary business expense and therefore, was not included on the employee's W2.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a Travel for companions
ExplntnTxt: Companion travel is the financial responsibility of the traveler except in cases where the presence of the companion is required for university business reasons and therefore is not included in the individual's W-2.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a Housing allowance or residence for personal use
ExplntnTxt: The University has three campuses, located in Stockton, Sacramento and San Francisco. At the main campus in Stockton and the Sacramento campus, on-campus housing is provided to the President and Dean, respectively. For Stockton and Sacramento, the housing qualifies for exclusion from employee taxable income. A housing allowance in the amount of $3,000 per month is provided to the Director of Athletics and is treated as taxable compensation. The Provost received a $40,000 forgiveness on a housing loan that was included in her W-2 and also within the "other reportable compensation" column of Schedule J.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a Health or social club dues or initiation fees
ExplntnTxt: Some University officers and key employees have University paid memberships in social, golf and country clubs to facilitate business purposes, including donor cultivation, networking and University meetings. Any personal use of such clubs are taxable to the employees and reported as a portion of the "other reportable compensation" on Schedule J Part II Column B(iii).

ExplntnTxt: President Eibeck's W-2 includes "other reportable compensation" of $10,642 for the value of all housekeeping services provided by the University at her on-campus residence. Housekeeping services for the Sacramento campus home is personally paid by the Dean.

The Executive Committee of the Board of Trustees consists of the Treasurer, Secretary and Chairman of the Board, which are all independent members of the Board of Trustees. The Committee is charged with reviewing and approving the compensation and benefits for the President. The Committee uses comparability data such as a survey issued to several private colleges regarding total compensation for a President conducted by an independent compensation consultant and salary data for private college administrator positions provided by a state association of independent private colleges. The data includes information from what Simpson College deems as their peer or comparable colleges and universities. The Committee is required to inform the full Board of Trustees of all provisions and elements of the President's compensation.

THIS IS A TAXABLE BENEFIT FOR THE EMPLOYEE BECAUSE THE SPOUSES DO NOT MEET THE BUSINESS PURPOSE REQUIREMENT. UNDER THE TERMS OF THE PLAN, PARTICIPANTS ARE ELIGIBLE FOR CERTAIN AWARDS BASED ON THE PERFORMANCE OF BOSTON COLLEGE'S INVESTMENTS EACH CALENDAR YEAR, AS MEASURED BY CERTAIN QUANTITATIVE AND QUALITATIVE FACTORS. A PORTION OF THE AWARD UNDER THE PLAN IS SUBJECT TO A TWO YEAR DEFERRAL PERIOD. THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES HAS THE OVERALL RESPONSIBILITY FOR THE COMPENSATION REVIEW OF THE PRESIDENT. AN ANNUAL REVIEW IS BASED ON FOUR FACTORS, SUMMATIVE PERFORMANCE APPRAISAL, ACHIEVEMENT OF ANNUAL GOALS, MARKET ANALYSIS AND INSTITUTIONAL NEEDS. THE PRESIDENT SUBMITS A STATUS REPORT ON THE CURRENT YEAR'S GOALS, YEAR END RESULTS AND PROPOSED GOALS FOR THE UPCOMING YEAR. THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE WILL ALSO RECEIVE APPROPRIATE PEER AND BENCHMARK DATA FROM THE HUMAN RESOURCES OFFICE. THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES WILL REVIEW THE PRESIDENT'S PERFORMANCE AND DISCUSS THEIR CONCLUSIONS ORALLY WITH THE PRESIDENT TO ENSURE THE ACCURATE AND FAIRNESS OF JUDGEMENTS. THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE WILL THEN DISCUSS ITS CONCLUSIONS AND COMPENSATION RECOMMENDATION WITH THE PRESIDENT. THE PRESIDENT HAS A WRITTEN EMPLOYMENT CONTRACT. THE PRESIDENT HAS THE OVERALL RESPONSIBILITY FOR THE COMPENSATION REVIEW OF THE VICE PRESIDENTS. A MARKET ANALYSIS IS DONE BY THE HUMAN RESOURCES OFFICE WHICH ALSO INCLUDES PEER AND BENCHAMARK DATA. THIS ANALYSIS IS THEN USED AS A TOOL FOR DETERMINING SALARY CHANGES AND IS REVIEWED WITH THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE PRIOR TO IMPLEMENTATION. THE SCHEDULE J ALSO DETAILS THE TOTAL COMPENSATION PAID TO THE INSTITUTE'S OFFICERS, KEY EMPLOYEES AND HIGHLY COMPENSATED EMPLOYEES. THE ABOVE SCHEDULE J, ALSO INCLUDES AMOUNTS CONTRIBUTED AND DISTRIBUTED FROM THE INSTITUTE'S EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION PLAN. ON JUNE 1ST OF EACH YEAR, THE INSTITUTE DEPOSITS AND INVESTS 10% OF EACH EXECUTIVE OFFICER'S BASE PAY INTO A DEFERRED COMPENSATION ASSET PLAN. THE INITIAL VALUE OF THESE DEPOSITS ARE INCLUDED IN THE "DEFERRED COMPENSATION" COLUMN ON SCHEDULE J. VESTING OCCURS 3 YEARS FOLLOWING THE INITIAL DEPOSIT. EVEN THOUGH THIS SCHEDULE RECOGNIZES DEFERRED COMPENSATION AS WAGES EARNED, THIS TYPE OF COMPENSATION MAY BE FORFEITED, IF THE OFFICER IS NO LONGER EMPLOYED AT THE INSTITUTE. YEARLY, THE VESTED DEPOSITS AND ANY ASSOCIATED REALIZED GAINS OR LOSSES WILL BE DISTRIBUTED TO EACH EXECUTIVE OFFICER. THESE DISTRIBUTIONS ARE INCLUDED IN THE "OTHER COMPENSATION" COLUMN IN SCHEDULE J. EFFECTIVELY, THE VALUE OF THE ORIGINAL DEPOSITS ARE BEING REPORTED AS COMPENSATION TWICE ON THE SCHEDULE J. COLUMN F, ON SCHEDULE J, SHOWS THE AMOUNTS WHICH ARE BEING DUPLICATED FROM THE PRIOR YEAR.
UPON SEPERATION FROM EMPLOYMENT WITH THE INSTITUTE, ROSE CHIN, RECEIVED A SEVERANCE PAYMENT OF $ 106,250..

TRAVEL FOR COMPANIONS: THE COLLEGE ONLY PAYS THE TRAVEL EXPENSES OF THE PRESIDENT'S SPOUSE IF THE PURPOSE OF HER TRIP IS RELATED TO COLLEGE BUSINESS. HOUSING ALLOWANCE OR RESIDENCE FOR PERSONAL USE: THE COLLEGE'S PRESIDENT IS PROVIDED WITH A HOUSE AS A CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT. THE HOUSE IS USED FOR BOTH BUSINESS AND PERSONAL PURPOSES. HOUSEKEEPING SERVICES FOR THE HOUSE ARE ALSO PROVIDED. PERSONAL SERVICES: THE COLLEGE PAYS FOR THE PRESIDENT'S TAX PREPARATION AND ESTATE PLANNING. TAX INDEMNIFICATION AND GROSS-UP PAYMENTS: ELIGIBLE COLLEGE EMPLOYEES RECEIVE AN ANNUAL RETIREMENT PLAN CONTRIBUTION FROM THE COLLEGE EQUAL TO 10% OF ELIGIBLE SALARY, SUBJECT TO IRS ANNUAL LIMITATIONS. BECAUSE THE PRESIDENT'S COMPENSATION TRIGGERS THE LIMITATION EFFECT, THE COLLEGE SUPPLEMENTS THE PRESIDENT'S ANNUAL CASH COMPENSATION WITH AN AMOUNT THAT BRINGS THE RETIREMENT PLAN CONTRIBUTION TO THE LEVEL OF OTHER PARTICIPANTS IN THE PLAN. THE COLLEGE OFFSETS THE INCOME TAX BURDEN OF THIS ADDITIONAL COMPENSATION BY GROSSING UP THE WAGES FOR THE YEAR. THIS ADDITIONAL COMPENSATION IS REPORTED ON THE EMPLOYEE'S W-2. THE COLLEGE SUPPLEMENTS THE LIFE INSURANCE OFFERED THROUGH ITS BENEFIT PLANS WITH AN ADDITIONAL POLICY FOR THE PRESIDENT OF THE COLLEGE. THE PRESIDENT PAYS THE ANNUAL PREMIUM FOR THE POLICY AND IS REIMBURSED BY THE COLLEGE. UNDER IRS RULES, SUCH PAYMENT MUST BE REPORTED AS TAXABLE COMPENSATION TO THE EMPLOYEE. THE COLLEGE OFFSETS THE INCOME TAX BURDEN OF THIS COMPENSATION BY GROSSING UP THE WAGES FOR THE YEAR. THIS ADDITIONAL COMPENSATION IS REPORTED ON THE EMPLOYEE'S W-2. THROUGH AUGUST 21, 2016, IT WAS THE COLLEGE'S PRACTICE TO OFFSET THE INCOME TAX BURDEN OF CERTAIN DOMESTIC PARTNER BENEFITS BY GROSSING UP THE AFFECTED EMPLOYEE'S WAGES. SEVERAL EMPLOYEES BENEFITED FROM THE PRACTICE, NONE OF WHICH ARE "LISTED PERSONS NOTED IN FORM 990, PART VII, SECTION A. ANY ADDITIONAL COMPENSATION RELATED TO THIS PRACTICE WAS REPORTED AS TAXABLE INCOME ON THE W-2'S FOR ALL AFFECTED EMPLOYEES.

THE COLLEGE'S PRESIDENT IS THE SOLE PARTICIPANT IN A NONQUALIFIED RETIREMENT PLAN. THE COLLEGE PLACED $100,000 IN THE PLAN DURING THE YEAR COVERED BY THIS REPORT. CERTAIN TIME-IN-SERVICE AND PERFORMANCE REQUIREMENTS MUST BE MET FOR THE PRESIDENT TO RECEIVE THE PLAN'S ASSETS.

SUPPLEMENTAL NONQUALIFIED DEFERRED COMPENSATION PLAN - DURING CALENDAR YEAR 2011, AS PART OF A NEW FIVE YEAR EMPLOYMENT CONTRACT, THE UNIVERSITY ENTERED INTO A SUPPLEMENTAL RETIREMENT AGREEMENT (SRA) WITH THE PRESIDENT. UNDER THE SRA, THE UNIVERSITY MAY MAKE DEFERRALS FROM 0 TO 30 PERCENT OF THE PRESIDENT'S BASE PAY, IN THE SOLE DISCRETION OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES, FOR EACH YEAR THROUGH THE FISCAL YEAR ENDING JUNE 30, 2016. AMOUNTS DEFERRED ARE SUBJECT TO FORFEITURE IF CERTAIN CONDITIONS ARE NOT MET IN THE DISCRETION OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES. FOR CALENDAR YEAR 2016, THE AMOUNT DEFERRED AND PAID WAS $100,000. THIS AMOUNT IS INCLUDED ON SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN B(ii) AS BONUS AND INCENTIVE COMPENSATION.

COMPENSATION OF $593,167 EARNED IN 2016 IS DETAILED AS FOLLOWS: 1A. $498,646 BASE COMPENSATION PLUS PRE-TAX EMPLOYEE DEDUCTIONS; 1B. $ 61,273 BENEFITS INCLUDING QUALIFIED RETIREMENT PLAN CONTRIBUTIONS; 1C. $ 33,248 BENEFITS RELATED TO ROLE AS PRESIDENT (HOUSING AND AUTO). DURING 2016, AS A RESULT OF SATISFYING ALL OF THE TERMS OF A SECTION 457(F) PLAN HELD IN HER NAME IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE SRA ENTERED INTO DURING 2011 FROM THE PREVIOUS EMPLOYMENT CONTRACT, THE PRESIDENT RECEIVED A DISTRIBUTION OF $961,537. THE AMOUNTS INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING: 3A. $698,709 PRIOR YEAR CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE SRA AS DISCLOSED ON FORM 990 EACH YEAR (2011 - $225,000; 2012 - $108,000; 2013 - $162,234; 2014 - $101,475; and 2015 - $102,000); 3B. $162,828 CUMULATIVE PLAN INVESTMENT EARNINGS ON PLAN ASSETS DURING THE DEFERRAL PERIOD; AND 3C. $100,000 2016 CONTRIBUTION TO THE SRA FOR THE CURRENT YEAR.

HOUSING ALLOWANCE OR RESIDENCE FOR PERSONAL USE BOTH THE PRESIDENT AND DEAN ARE ORDAINED MINISTERS ENTITLED TO A MINISTERIAL HOUSING ALLOWANCE. THE SCHOOL THEN REIMBURSES SPOUSAL TRAVEL USING THE SAME DOCUMENTATION REQUIREMENTS AS ALL OTHER TRAVEL EXPENSES, INCLUDING A REVIEW FOR THE APPROPRIATE TAX TREATMENTS PER POLICY. THESE TRAVEL EXPENSES WERE NOT TREATED AS TAXABLE COMPENSATION.

The Board shall pay or reimburse the President and President's spouse for reasonable entertainment expenses, travel expenses, hotel bills, and other necessary expenses to further the interests of the University. Amounts that are personal are included in taxable wages. The Board provides a taxable housing allowance of $33,000 per year and a taxable automobile allowance of $13,200 per year. The Board will provide the President, at University expense, with membership in business clubs, service organizations and professional organizations that would further the interests of the University. Any personal use of the membership dues are included in taxable wages.

George Fox owns a home that is suitable for University events and functions that are hosted by the university president and his/her spouse. The President is provided with this housing and the benefit is not included in taxable income. In order to enhance the influence of the University in the local community, Arlington Club dues are paid for the president. The Arlington Club provides a forum for networking within the business community to find people interested in investing time and resources in higher education. Dues paid are not included in taxable income. The president's spouse's attendance is required for some events and functions. Travel for those events/functions is considered to be an ordinary and necessary business expense for the President's spouse to accompany him and therefore is not included in taxable income.

An across the board bonus was accrued for all non-officer employees (including Highest Compensated Employees listed in 990, Part VII, Section A, line 1a) based on a board mandated formula based on a specific calculation of Unrestricted Net Earnings. The bonuses were accrued in the current tax year, to be paid in the next fiscal year.
Non-fixed bonuses are awarded based on achievement of specific performance metrics.

For flights greater than 4 hours, the President is approved to travel in Business Class or First Class if Business Class is not available on the flight. These expenses are not included in the President's taxable fringe benefits. The President's spouse is expected to accompany the President on University business travel where appropriate and the related travel expenses are not a taxable fringe benefit. The University requires the President to live in a University owned residence. Personal services provided to the President are limited to custodial cleaning of the residence. The President also receives tax gross-up payments relating to the personal use benefit of the residence. The personal use value of the residence is reported as a portion of "other reportable compensation" on Schedule J, Part II. FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a Travel for companions
ExplntnTxt: the organization provided the following to the former president Carol Ann Mooney: Travel expenses for a spouse are reimbursable if it can be shown that the person's presence was directly related to the effective accomplishment of College business. The President is often required to have extensive and unique contact with key constituencies on behalf of the College. When performing official duties in such areas as development, alumni, college relations, and professional organizations (and because spouses make an important contribution to the success of these events), the College will pay the spouse's travel expenses if both the following conditions are met: (1) The spouse attends and contributes to the official function. This includes events when the spouses of the College's guests are expected to be present. (2) The purpose of the travel and the expenses incurred are fully documented and the activities of the spouse relating to College business are outlined. Since the travel expenses paid on behalf of the President's spouse met the two conditions stated above and were for business purposes, the amount is not included in the President's taxable compensation. No such benefit is provided for the current president.

SUPPLEMENTAL NONQUALIFIED PLANS FORM 990, SCHEDULE J, PART I, LINE 4B DANIELE STRUPPA ENTERED INTO A RETENTION BONUS AGREEMENT DATED SEPTEMBER 27, 2011 UNDER IRC SECTIONS 409(A) AND 457 (F). ALL TERMS OF THE AGREEMENT WERE MET IN 2016 WHEN FULL PAYMENT WAS MADE. AMOUNTS PAID UNDER THE AGREEMENT ARE INCLUDED IN PART II, COLUMN (B)(III) AND (F). DANIELE STRUPPA PARTICIPATES IN A SECTION 457(F) COMPENSATION PLAN. THIS COMPENSATION ARRANGEMENT PROVIDES FOR FIVE (5) ANNUAL PAYMENTS OF $100,000 TO BE CREDITED TO THE EMPLOYEE'S ACCOUNT EACH YEAR WITH AN INTEREST RATE EQUAL TO THE TEN (10) YEAR TREASURY BOND RATE THROUGH AUGUST 31, 2021. THESE PAYMENTS ARE SUBJECT TO CONTINUED EMPLOYMENT THROUGH AUGUST 31, 2021. IN THE EVENT THAT DANIELE STRUPPA INCURS A DISABILITY OR DIES, HIS DESIGNATED BENEFICIARY SHALL BE ENTITLED TO RECEIVE PAYMENT. ON AUGUST 26, 2016, DANIELE STRUPPA ENTERED INTO AN ADDITIONAL NON-QUALIFIED DEFERRED COMPENSATION PLAN. THE PLAN WILL PROVIDE $60,000 ON AUGUST 31 OF EACH YEAR BEGINNING IN 2017 THROUGH AND INCLUDING 2021. THESE PAYMENTS ARE CONTINGENT UPON CONTINUED EMPLOYMENT AS PRESIDENT OF THE UNIVERSITY THROUGH AUGUST 31, 2021. THESE AMOUNTS WILL VEST UPON THE EARLIER OF AUGUST 31, 2021 OR TERMINATION OF EMPLOYMENT AS PRESIDENT. EXECUTIVE RETENTION BONUS AGREEMENT GARY BRAHM, CHARLES BULLOCK AND SASKIA KNIGHT (EXECUTIVES) PARTICIPATE IN A SUPPLEMENTAL NONQUALIFIED 457(F) PLAN (AKA THE EXECUTIVE RETENTION BONUS PLAN), EFFECTIVE FEBRUARY 14, 2013. UNDER THE TERMS OF THE PLAN, THE BONUS IS CALCULATED AT 2% OF THE UNIVERSITY'S EXCESS SURPLUS FOR THE FISCAL YEAR JUNE 1, 2017 THROUGH MAY 31, 2018 (BASE YEAR), CAPPED AT THE GREATER OF THE EXECUTIVE'S HIGHEST ANNUAL BASE SALARY DURING THE BASE YEAR OR DURING THE PRIOR FISCAL YEAR. IN ADDITION, THE EXECUTIVE WILL RECEIVE A PAYMENT EQUAL TO THE PRESENT VALUE OF A SERIES OF PAYMENTS THAT WOULD BE MADE ON THE NINE CONSECUTIVE ANNIVERSARIES OF THE LAST DAY OF THE BASE YEAR, DISCOUNTED AT 3% PER ANNUM. A ONE-TIME DEFERRAL OPTION IS AVAILABLE TO THE EXECUTIVE TO ELECT JUNE 1, 2021 THROUGH MAY 31, 2022 AS THE BASE YEAR FOR THE BONUS AMOUNT. TO DATE, THERE HAVE NOT BEEN ANY "SURPLUS EARNINGSNO AMOUNTS ARE ACCRUED OR OWING UNDER THE PLAN. THESE PLANS WERE VOLUNTARILY TERMINATED IN FEBRUARY 2017. JAMES DOTI ENTERED INTO A RETENTION BONUS AGREEMENT DATED SEPTEMBER 23, 2011 UNDER IRC SECTIONS 409(A) AND 457(F). ALL TERMS OF THE AGREEMENT WERE MET IN 2016 WHEN FULL PAYMENT WAS MADE. AMOUNTS PAID UNDER THE AGREEMENT ARE INCLUDED IN PART II, COLUMN(B)(III) AND (F).

TRAVEL FOR COMPANIONS: HOUSTON METHODIST HOSPITAL REQUIRES ALL EMPLOYEES INCLUDING OFFICERS TO PROVIDE WRITTEN SUBSTANTIATION OF EXPENSES RELATED TO THEIR BUSINESS TRAVEL THROUGH THE PROVISION OF DETAILED RECEIPTS IN ORDER TO RECEIVE APPROVAL FROM THEIR DIRECT SUPERIORS FOR REIMBURSEMENT IN ACCORDANCE WITH OUR CORPORATE POLICY ON TRAVEL AND OTHER BUSINESS EXPENSES. IN 2016, THE PRESIDENT/CEO HAD 1 TRIP APPROVED FOR ATTENDANCE AT AN OUT OF STATE MEETING WHERE IT WAS DEEMED APPROPRIATE BY THE CHAIR OF OUR BOARD THAT THE ATTENDANCE OF THE PRESIDENT/CEO'S SPOUSE (AND THE RELATED EXPENSES FOR HER TRAVEL TO THESE MEETINGS) WAS INTEGRAL TO CONDUCTING EFFECTIVE METHODIST BUSINESS AT THESE MEETINGS. PART I, LINE 4A: HOUSTON METHODIST HOSPITAL HAS A FORMAL SEVERANCE PLAN. ELIGIBLE EMPLOYEES INCLUDE ALL FULL-TIME AND PART-TIME STAFF (NOT TEMPORARY OR PRN), INCLUDING HOURLY STAFF, UP THROUGH SENIOR VICE PRESIDENTS PROVIDED THEY WORK AT LEAST 20 HOURS PER WEEK AND ARE NOT OTHERWISE COVERED BY A PHYSICIAN EMPLOYMENT AGREEMENT. THE PLAN ONLY PROVIDES SALARY AND BENEFITS IN THE EVENT AN ELIGIBLE EMPLOYEE IS INVOLUNTARILY TERMINATED DUE TO THE ELIMINATION OF THEIR POSITION OR IF THEIR CURRENT POSITION IS SIGNIFICANTLY IMPACTED BY AN ORGANIZATIONAL RESTRUCTURING OR CHANGE IN REQUIREMENT AND A COMPARABLE POSITION IS NOT AVAILABLE WITHIN THE ORGANIZATION. THE ELIGIBLE PERSON MUST ALSO SIGN A TERMINATION AGREEMENT IN ORDER TO RECEIVE SALARY CONTINUATION AND BENEFITS UNDER THE PLAN TO WHICH THEY WOULD NOT NORMALLY BE ELIGIBLE TO RECEIVE UNDER A VOLUNTARY RESIGNATION. PURSUANT TO TREASURY REG SECTION 1 6033-2(D)(5), HOUSTON METHODIST HOSPITAL HAS ELECTED TO REPORT INFORMATION ABOUT CONTRIBUTIONS, GIFTS & GRANTS, COMPENSATION AND OTHER INFORMATION ABOUT OFFICERS, DIRECTORS, TRUSTEES, KEY EMPLOYEES, FORMER EMPLOYEES, CERTAIN OTHER HIGHLY PAID EMPLOYEES, CERTAIN PROFESSIONAL CONTRACTORS AND CERTAIN OTHER CONTRACTORS ON A CONSOLIDATED BASIS FOR ALL OF THE MEMBERS OF THE GROUP, INCLUDING THE PARENT ORGANIZATION, ON THE GROUP RETURN OF METHODIST HOSPITAL GROUP, EIN 35-2410801.

HOUSTON METHODIST HOSPITAL HAS A SUPPLEMENTAL EXECUTIVE RETIREMENT PLAN, A NON-QUALIFIED EMPLOYER FUNDED PLAN. CONTRIBUTIONS ARE MADE ANNUALLY INTO A TAX DEFERRED ACCOUNT AND ARE CONSIDERED TAXABLE UPON VESTING (I.E. COMPLETION OF THREE YEARS OF VESTING SERVICE). ONCE VESTED, EACH YEAR'S SUBSEQUENT CONTRIBUTION IS TAXABLE WITHIN THE CALENDAR YEAR IN WHICH THE DEPOSIT WAS MADE. ACCOUNT BALANCES CANNOT BE ACCESSED UNTIL RETIREMENT OR TERMINATION (WHICHEVER OCCURS FIRST) AND MAY BE SUBJECT TO NON-REVOCABLE DISTRIBUTION OPTIONS UPON ELECTION.

THIS ORGANIZATION PROVIDES VARIABLE COMPENSATION OPPORTUNITY THROUGH AN ANNUAL MANAGEMENT INCENTIVE PLAN. EXECUTIVES AT THE VICE PRESIDENT LEVEL AND ABOVE MAY BE ELIGIBLE TO PARTICIPATE. THE ANNUAL INCENTIVE PROGRAM IS BASED ON SYSTEM AND OPERATING ENTITY LEVEL PERFORMANCE IN THE AREAS OF QUALITY IMPROVEMENT OUTCOMES, PATIENT SATISFACTION AND FINANCIAL PERFORMANCE. IN ADDITION, A PORTION OF THE PAYOUT PERCENTAGE IS BASED ON GOALS THAT ARE SPECIFIC TO THE PARTICIPANTS' MANAGEMENT ROLES AT THE DIVISION OR DEPARTMENT LEVEL INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO SUCH METRICS AS OPERATING RESULTS, QUALITY AND SAFETY IMPROVEMENTS, CUSTOMER SATISFACTION MEASURES, GROWTH AND INNOVATION INITIATIVES. DETERMINATION OF A PARTICIPANT'S PERCENTAGE OF THE POTENTIAL BONUS PAYOUT (PAID AS A PERCENT OF BASE SALARY) IS BASED ON WHETHER THE INDIVIDUAL ATTAINS AGREED UPON GOALS FOR THEIR AREA OF RESPONSIBILITY AS DETERMINED BY THEIR IMMEDIATE SUPERVISOR.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a First-class or charter travel
ExplntnTxt: The University's written travel policy permits payment only of necessary and reasonable expenses for travel on University business. The University's policies constitute an accountable plan and are designed to comply with applicable Internal Revenue Service rules. Coach class airfare is required except in certain limited circumstances; these include medical necessity, contractual obligations, and scheduled flight segments over six hours in length, when business class fares may be used with prior approval. In rare cases, when an exception applies and no business class fare is available, a first class fare may be used, again with prior approval and documentation. Charter travel is sometimes employed for athletics teams, including coaches, when such travel is the least costly method of transportation.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a Travel for companions
ExplntnTxt: Under the University's travel policy, the University does not pay the travel cost of companions, unless there is a valid University business purpose for the companion's travel. Written approval must be obtained in advance from the president, provost, or appropriate dean / vice president documenting the reason for incurring the expense. When the University uses chartered air or ground transportation, travel for companions may occasionally be included if the University incurs no additional cost.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a Tax indemnification and gross-up payments
ExplntnTxt: Under the terms of his contract, the President is provided with grossed up payments for dependent tuition reimbursement. Tuition reimbursement of $11,248 was paid and grossed up to $17,765. The entire amount was taxable. Under the terms of the appointment letter, the Provost was provided with grossed up payments as reimbursement for rent and utilities while also maintaining a house in another state during her transition. Expenses of $36,469 were paid and the payment was grossed up to $50,198. The entire amount was taxable compensation.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a Housing allowance or residence for personal use
ExplntnTxt: The president of the University is required to occupy University-owned housing as a condition of employment. Housekeeping staff is provided for such property. The cost of such services not related to public areas of the house is included in compensation reported. The fair market value of the housing provided, based on the appraised value of the house, is reported in the president's compensation as a non-taxable benefit. Beginning July 1, 2017 the provost was paid a housing allowance. This amount is fully taxable.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a Health or social club dues or initiation fees
ExplntnTxt: Social club dues were paid for the president of the University and included in compensation as appropriate.

ExplntnTxt: See the response to Schedule J, Part I, Line 1A for Housing

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 3 Arrangement used to establish the top management official's compensation
ExplntnTxt: The CORD (Compensation and Organizational Development) Committee of the Board of Trustees of Rice University has a written procedure in place to assure the Board of Trustees that compensation arrangements for the president and other organization officers and managers are reasonable. The procedure is designed to comply with the requirements of Section 4958 of the Internal Revenue Code and Internal Revenue Service regulations. The CORD Committee maintains a roster of disqualified persons, as defined by the IRS, for whose compensation the procedure is used. The roster is reviewed periodically but at least annually. The procedure was last discussed with the full board in March 2011. The procedure requires three elements as follows: 1) The terms of transactions are approved by the organization's governing body, or a committee thereof, whose members have no conflict of interest with respect to the arrangement. The Board of Trustees delegated authority to the CORD Committee to act on behalf of the Board in these matters at its meeting on March 25, 1999. Compensation arrangements are reviewed and approved by the CORD Committee before the effective date. Members of the CORD Committee recuse themselves from any vote in which there is a potential or actual conflict of interest. 2) The governing body or committee obtains and relies upon appropriate, comparable data before making its determination. Rice participates in the annual survey by Willis Towers Watson of select universities' executive compensation, and additional appropriate peer surveys. These reports reflect executive compensation in universities of a stature similar to that of Rice, and with which Rice competes for faculty and staff. The CORD Committee may also seek and rely on other relevant information, including compensation paid by other taxable and tax-exempt organizations for functionally comparable positions, geographic market forces, and actual written offers from similar institutions competing for services. The CORD Committee relies on this data and documents any determinations that reasonable compensation is an amount more than the range of comparable data. 3) The governing body or committee adequately documents the basis for making determinations concurrently with making decisions. Minutes documenting the deliberations of the CORD Committee are prepared contemporaneously for review and approval at its next meeting.

The University provides on-campus housing for Rev. Kevin P. Quinn, S.J., President. The estimated value of housing is $17,668. The housing values are based upon residence hall rates charged to University students. The housing value is included in the President's compensation disclosed in Part VII of the Form 990. The University pays for initiation fees and monthly dues for a membership for the President to the Scranton Country Club. The University also pays for the annual membership fees for the Vice President for University Advancement in his role at the following social clubs: Pyramid Club of Philadelphia, Hamilton Farm Golf Club of Gladstone, NJ, and Glenmaura National Golf Club of Moosic, PA. These memberships are used by senior administrators to host meetings with business partners of the University, Board of Trustees members, potential donors, and faculty and staff. Membership in these clubs allows for reciprocal use of other related venues within the United States. These reciprocal agreements allow senior administration to host quality business and fundraising events outside the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania.

The Executive Compensation Committee of the Board of Trustees reviews appropriate analyses and studies prepared by the Human Resources Office or external sources to aid in evaluating compensation and benefits and strategies to attract and retain qualified personnel for senior executive administrative positions. The Committee annually reviews and approves compensation and benefits for senior administrators and officers of the University. This review includes comparable market data for positions at other higher education institutions. The Committee reports to the Executive Committee of the Board of Trustees the total compensation paid to the University's president and vice presidents. The Committee reviews the recommendations of, and advises, the President as to the individual employment contracts that are above and beyond the scope of the University's base compensation and benefits structure.

Coaches listed in Form 990, Part VII, travel with the team on these occasions. None of the benefit is taxable compensation. President's Housing: The president is provided housing near campus for the convenience of the University as a condition of employment so that he can fully engage in campus life, entertain students, donors and faculty; for proximity to the campus for many evening events; and to be nearby in the event of emergencies. Additionally, the president uses the employer-provided house for significant business use, such as entertaining donors, University meetings and other business activities. None of the benefit is taxable compensation. Tax indemnification and gross-up payments: Other reportable compensation for the president includes a supplemental payment for his retirement plan and the related tax gross up.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMNS C AND D
ExplntnTxt: CORNELL UNIVERSITY PROVIDES A WIDE VARIETY OF BENEFITS TO ITS EMPLOYEES. BENEFITS ARE TREATED AS A NON-TAXABLE BENEFIT, A PRE-TAX EMPLOYEE DEDUCTION, A POST-TAX EMPLOYEE DEDUCTION, OR OTHERWISE RECORDED AS TAXABLE INCOME. COMPENSATION REVIEW ------------------- EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION FOR THE HEALTH NETWORK CONSISTS OF FIXED SALARY, AT-RISK COMPENSATION AND OTHER DEFERRED COMPENSATION ARRANGEMENTS. TOTAL COMPENSATION FOR NETWORK EXECUTIVES IS APPROVED ANNUALLY BY THE NETWORK'S BOARD OF DIRECTORS. THE RECOMMENDED COMPENSATION IS ESTABLISHED THROUGH A MULTI-FACETED APPROACH INCLUDING USE OF AN INDEPENDENT CONSULTANT ENGAGED ON AN ONGOING BASIS BY THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS AND WHO WORKS DIRECTLY WITH THE EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD. ALSO INCLUDED IS THE REVIEW OF FORMS 990 AND COMPENSATION SURVEYS OF OTHER COMPARABLE HEALTHCARE ORGANIZATIONS. BONUS/INCENTIVE --------------- THE AT-RISK COMPENSATION IS APPROVED BY THE EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD AND IS BASED ON SEVERAL QUALITATIVE AND QUANTITATIVE COMPONENTS, INCLUDING JOINT COMMISSION, PENNSYLVANIA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND PENNSYLVANIA TRAUMA SYSTEMS FOUNDATION ACCREDITATIONS, EVIDENCE-BASED HOSPITAL PROCESS OF CARE MEASURES, OUTCOME MEASURES, SUCH AS PATIENT SATISFACTION, MORTALITY RATE, AND LENGTH OF STAY; EFFICIENCY MEASURES AS DEMONSTRATED BY COST-PER-ADJUSTED DISCHARGE AND NET INCOME. OTHER REPORTABLE COMPENSATION ----------------------------- OTHER BENEFITS INCLUDE DEFERRED COMPENSATION BENEFITS THAT HAD ACCUMULATED OVER YEARS OF SERVICE AND WAS REPORTED AND DISTRIBUTED IN ACCORDANCE WITH VESTING REQUIREMENTS AND INTERNAL REVENUE SERVICE RULES AND REGULATIONS. DEFERRED COMPENSATION --------------------- DEFERRED COMPENSATION REPRESENTS RETIREMENT BENEFITS EARNED DURING THE REPORTING PERIOD, NOT RECOGNIZED AS COMPENSATION ON THE EMPLOYEE'S 2016 FORM W-2. NONTAXABLE BENEFITS ------------------- NONTAXABLE BENEFITS REPRESENTS HEALTH AND WELFARE BENEFITS RECEIVED DURING THE REPORTING PERIOD, NOT RECOGNIZED AS COMPENSATION ON THE EMPLOYEE'S 2016 FORM W-2. COMPENSATION REPORTED ON PRIOR 990 ---------------------------------- TOTAL COMPENSATION REPORTED ON PRIOR FORMS 990 REPRESENTS RECOGNITION OF DEFERRED COMPENSATION BENEFITS THAT HAD ACCUMULATED OVER YEARS OF SERVICE AND WAS REPORTED AND DISTRIBUTED IN ACCORDANCE WITH VESTING REQUIREMENTS AND INTERNAL REVENUE SERVICE RULES AND REGULATIONS. THESE AMOUNTS WERE PREVIOUSLY REPORTED IN SCHEDULE J, COLUMN B(III) - OTHER COMPENSATION.

FIRST-CLASS OR CHARTER TRAVEL: THE UNIVERSITY USES CHARTER AIR TRAVEL PRIMARILY TO TRANSPORT THE FOOTBALL TEAM AND THE MEN'S AND WOMEN'S BASKETBALL TEAMS TO AWAY GAME VENUES. OCCASIONALLY, DUE TO TIME CONSTRAINTS, WEATHER CONCERNS, OR CLOSELY SEQUENCED COMMITMENTS, SENIOR MANAGEMENT MAY USE CHARTER AIR TRAVEL TO MEET PROFESSIONAL RESPONSIBILITIES. TRAVEL IS TREATED AS TAXABLE INCOME ON FORM W-2 IF NOT FOR BONA FIDE BUSINESS PURPOSES. TRAVEL FOR COMPANIONS: TRAVEL FOR COMPANIONS IS TREATED AS TAXABLE INCOME ON FORM W-2. TAX INDEMNIFICATION AND GROSS-UP PAYMENTS: CERTAIN SENIOR OFFICERS AT THE UNIVERSITY ARE ELIGIBLE FOR A HEALTH CARE PACKAGE UP TO A MAXIMUM AMOUNT OF $5,000 PER YEAR. THE REIMBURSEMENT IS "GROSSED-UP" FOR INCOME TAX PURPOSES. HOUSING ALLOWANCE OR RESIDENCE FOR PERSONAL USE: AS A CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT, THE CHANCELLOR IS REQUIRED TO LIVE IN A RESIDENCE PROVIDED BY THE UNIVERSITY TO MEET WITH AND ENTERTAIN DONORS, PROSPECTIVE DONORS, INSTITUTIONAL SUPPORTERS, AND BUSINESS ASSOCIATES.USE OF THE RESIDENCE IS NOT CONSIDERED TAXABLE INCOME UNDER IRC SEC. 119(D). HEALTH OR SOCIAL CLUB DUES OR INITIATION FEES: BECAUSE CERTAIN OFFICERS OF THE UNIVERSITY ARE REQUIRED TO ENTERTAIN DONORS, PROSPECTIVE DONORS, INSTITUTIONAL SUPPORTERS, AND BUSINESS ASSOCIATES, CLUB MEMBERSHIPS ARE PROVIDED. PERSONAL USE OF CLUB MEMBERSHIPS IS TREATED AS TAXABLE INCOME ON FORM W-2. PERSONAL SERVICES: FINANCIAL CONSULTING SERVICES UP TO A MAXIMUM AMOUNT OF $5,000 PER YEAR ARE PROVIDED TO CERTAIN SENIOR OFFICERS OF THE UNIVERSITY AND ARE TREATED AS TAXABLE INCOME ON FORM W-2.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Part I, Line 1a: Relevant information in regards to selections on 1a.
Part I, Line 1b: Reason for not following policy regarding payment provisions for expenses
ExplntnTxt: The President is the only employee eligible for first class and spousal/companion travel. Other executives may be approved based on demonstrated medical need only. Rensselaer's President is allowed to use first class travel on Rensselaer business in accordance with the terms of her employment agreement, which was approved by independent members of the Compensation and Personnel Development Committee. The President's expenses are subject to review by the Board of Trustees, including any amounts for spousal or companion travel. The Board has oversight of strategic issues for facilities management, which include but are not limited to capital improvements and other costs for Rensselaer's president's residence. The Board of Rensselaer also oversees the review and audit of expenses of the President relating to the presidential residence and personal services associated with the upkeep of the residence. Such review occurs under the Board's oversight on an at least annual basis.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Part I, Line 7: Non-Fixed payments not listed above
ExplntnTxt: Rensselaer maintains a performance incentive program in connection with the annual evaluation process for its President and Executive Officers. Eligibility for receipt of such incentive payments is limited to certain Executive Officers. Performance awards are made following the evaluative process and subject to review by the Compensation and Personnel Development Committee of the Board based upon such annual evaluations, with the amount of such awards, if any, at its discretion subject to applicable maximum limits by employment contract.

Part II - As noted in Column B(iii) and consistent with applicable federal guidance, executive positions with primary responsibility for endowment management and enrollement are not eligible for incentive compensation.

Travel for companions and gross up payments were provided to an officer of the University. These benefits were provided as taxable compensation. The non-taxable benefit is included in Part II, Column D. A personal residence was provided to the President as a mandatory condition of employment and was not taxable based on section 119 of IRC.

The President participates in a non qualified deferred compensation retirement plan. The plan was created during 2010 with the approval of the Executive Committee, an independent and disinterested party, in order to align the President's total compensation with comparable universities and to ensure the President's long-term employment with Clarkson University. The current year distribution from the plan was $400,000, plus accrued interest, for a total of $413,849. This distribution included $200,000 of prior year contributions, which have been previously reported on Form 990 over the past two years. The current year contribution to the plan amounted to $100,000.

The Executive Committee may, at its discretion, award the President a performance award each year in connection with an evaluation of his performance. The evaluation is based upon his accomplishments against goals and objectives during the year.

THE ORGANIZATION USES COMPARABILITY DATA FROM FORMS 990 OF OTHER SIMILAR ORGANIZATIONS AND FROM A COMPENSATION STUDY TO DETERMINE THE SALARIES FOR THE PRESIDENT/CEO AND OTHER OFFICERS. THE PRESIDENT/CEO'S SALARY IS DETERMINED AND APPROVED BY THE INDEPENDENT BOARD OF DIRECTORS ANNUALLY AFTER REVIEWING COMPARABILITY DATA.

Housing Allowance & Personal Services: As a condition of employment, and as a convenience to the University, the President is provided a home on University grounds. The University also provides grounds care and housekeeping for the home since the President hosts functions for the University at his home. The home is provided as a nontaxable benefit to the President.
